Properties

Properties are handled in the same way as variables, but in reality, they involve calls to a setter and a getter, similar to method calls. Setters and getters are sometimes called property handlers.

The syntax is as follows:

property identifier
{
    setter(argument)
    {
        // Setter content goes here
    }

    getter()
    {
        // Getter content goes here
        return expression; // Value returned as the getter
    }
}
The setter and getter may be written in either order.
The property is registered as a member of the class in which it is described, or as a global member, but the acquisition of a value from this identifier is done through the getter, and the setting of a value is done through the setter. These setters and getters can contain various contents just like methods. The setter takes a variable to receive the value as an argument in the ( ) following "setter". The getter returns a value using the return statement.

The () after the getter can be omitted.

By writing both a setter and a getter for one identifier, it becomes a property that is both readable and writable. If you write only one, for example only a getter, it becomes a read-only property and writing to it will result in an error.

Example:
    var value;

    property property1 // Declare property 'property1'
    {
        setter(v)
        {
            // The setter takes only one argument
            value=v; // Process argument v

            inform("value set.");
        }

        getter
        {
            // Declare getter for the same identifier 'property1' as the setter
            // Getters have no arguments
            inform("value get.");
            return value; // Return as a return value
        }
    }

    property1=5; // Assignment to property1 calls the setter
    property1++; // In an expression like this, the getter is called,
                 // and then the setter is called and the value is set
}
Like variables, functions, and classes, properties can also be overridden.

Property Objects

A property itself is also an object. However, when it is registered in some object, normal access methods only call the property handler, and the property object itself cannot be accessed.
To retrieve the property object itself, use the & operator. The retrieved property object can be placed into a local variable.
Also, a property object can be registered using the & operator.

Example:
    property prop // Declare property prop
    {
        (omitted)
    }

{
    var p = &prop; // Get property object and put into local variable

    &object.property1 = p; // Register p as property1 of object
}

Using the & operator allows access to the property object itself without calling the getter or setter. Without the & operator, it is a normal property access.

A property object retrieved as a local variable can have its property handler called using the * operator, even without registering it to an object.


Example:
    property prop // Declare property prop
    {
        (omitted)
    }

{
    var p = &prop; // Get property object and put into local variable

    *p = 30; // Call the setter and set it to 30
    func(*p); // Call the getter to retrieve the value and pass it to func
}

Note
When taking a property object into a var variable as above, please make the variable a local variable. This is because once a property object is registered to an object, it begins to behave as a property via getters and setters, rather than as a property object. In other words, if you register a property object as a global variable (= member of global) or as a member of an object instead of a local variable, it will behave just like a normal property. Of course, it is perfectly fine to use the & operator to retrieve a property object that has been registered to a global variable or object member in this way.


Using the instanceof operator with "Property" on a property object will return true (in the above example, &prop instanceof "Property" is true).
